brief_summary: Mass killing of Palestinian civilians and prisoners of war during the 1948 Arab-Israeli War. Bodies were buried in mass graves.

executiveSummary.title: Executive Summary

alert.text: War Crime Classification: Mass execution of civilians and prisoners of war, summary executions, concealment of evidence through mass burial.

paragraphs: On May 22-23, 1948, the Alexandroni Brigade of the Haganah (which became the IDF) attacked the Palestinian coastal village of Tantura. After the village surrendered, an estimated 200-250 Palestinian men were systematically executed and buried in mass graves. The massacre was suppressed for over 50 years.

The village of Tantura had a population of approximately 1,500 people and was known for its fishing industry. Despite attempts at surrender and raising white flags, Israeli forces conducted house-to-house searches, separated men from women and children, and executed male villagers. Bodies were buried in multiple mass graves, including one beneath what is now the parking lot of Dor Beach.

The massacre remained largely unknown until 1998 when Israeli graduate student Teddy Katz documented it through interviews with both Palestinian survivors and Israeli soldiers who participated. Despite initial confirmation by veterans, Katz faced a libel lawsuit, and Israeli authorities have consistently refused to excavate the mass graves or conduct official investigations.

breakdown.label: Deaths
breakdown.detail: Primarily men aged 15-60, executed after surrender

breakdown.label: Injured
breakdown.detail: Most male captives were killed rather than detained

alert.text: Data Sources: Survivor testimonies, Israeli soldier testimonies (Teddy Katz research), academic documentation. Exact toll disputed; estimates range from 90 to 250. Most reliable estimates center on 200-250 executed men.

events.title: Attack Begins
events.description: Alexandroni Brigade attacks Tantura from land and sea. Village largely defenseless with minimal weapons.

events.title: Village Surrenders
events.description: Village elders raise white flags and negotiate surrender. Villagers told they will be safe if they comply.

events.title: Separation
events.description: Men separated from women and children. Males aged 15-60 gathered in village square and on the beach.

events.title: Mass Executions
events.description: Systematic execution of male prisoners throughout the day and into the night. Groups taken to execution sites and shot.

events.title: Mass Burial
events.description: Bodies buried in mass graves at various locations including the beach and cemetery. Some survivors forced to dig graves.

events.title: Expulsion
events.description: Surviving women, children, and elderly expelled from village. Many sent to Furaydis. Village looted and later demolished.

events.title: Cover-up
events.description: Kibbutz Nahsholim built on village ruins. Parking lot constructed over mass grave. Massacre suppressed from Israeli history.

alert.text: Content Warning: Graphic descriptions of mass executions and war crimes documented for historical record.

crimes.title: Mass Execution of Prisoners of War
crimes.description: After the village surrendered, male prisoners were systematically executed. Israeli soldier testimony: "They lined them up and shot them... I participated in the whole thing." Violations of laws of war regarding treatment of POWs.

crimes.title: Executions on the Beach
crimes.description: Multiple testimonies describe executions carried out on Tantura beach. Survivor: "They took the men in groups... we heard shooting. They didn't come back." Bodies left on beach before burial.

crimes.title: Mass Graves and Concealment
crimes.description: Bodies buried in multiple mass graves. One grave beneath current parking lot of Dor Beach. Israeli authorities refuse to allow excavation or investigation. Deliberate concealment of evidence.

crimes.title: Separation of Families
crimes.description: Deliberate separation of men from women and children before executions. Women and children forced to witness aftermath and used as forced labor to bury bodies.

crimes.title: Looting and Destruction
crimes.description: Systematic looting of homes, theft of valuables, fishing boats, and property. Village completely demolished. Kibbutz Nahsholim established on village lands.

crimes.title: Forced Expulsion
crimes.description: Surviving population forcibly expelled to nearby villages. Prevented from returning or burying their dead. Property confiscated under Israeli Absentee Property Law.

internationalLaw.title: International Law Violations
internationalLaw.introduction: The Tantura massacre violated multiple principles of international humanitarian law, particularly regarding treatment of prisoners of war and civilians:

sections.heading: Under Geneva Conventions (1949)
violations: Article 3: Prohibition of violence to life and person, including murder of persons taking no active part in hostilities
Article 13: Prisoners of war must be treated humanely - summary execution explicitly prohibited
Article 17: Protection of civilians and civilian property

sections.heading: Under Hague Conventions (1899, 1907)
violations: Article 23: Prohibition of killing or wounding enemy who has surrendered
Article 46: Protection of family honor and rights, individual lives and private property

sections.heading: Modern Classification (Rome Statute)
violations: Crimes Against Humanity: Murder, deportation or forcible transfer of population, persecution
War Crimes: Willful killing of protected persons, murder of POWs, extensive destruction and appropriation of property not justified by military necessity

alert.text: Legal Status: Mass execution of POWs is one of the most serious war crimes under international law. Despite documentation, no perpetrators were prosecuted. Israeli authorities continue to suppress evidence and refuse excavation of mass graves.
Content Warning: Graphic first-hand accounts of mass executions included for historical documentation.

witnesses.name: Anonymous Alexandroni Brigade Soldier
witnesses.testimony: There was no battle. They raised white flags... We gathered the men and took them. Some were taken to the cemetery, others to the beach. They lined them up and shot them. I participated in the whole thing.

witnesses.name: Mariam Al-Yahya
witnesses.testimony: They separated the men from us. We heard shooting all day and into the night. In the morning, we were told to leave. We never saw our men again. My father, my two brothers, my uncle - all gone.
witnesses.source: Survivor testimony documented by Teddy Katz, 1998

witnesses.name: Binyamin Shechter
witnesses.testimony: I know of three locations where people were killed and buried: the cemetery, the beach south of the village, and near the village well. The numbers? I estimate about 200-230 people were killed.

witnesses.name: Haim Hermesh
witnesses.testimony: They took them in groups, men aged 15 and up. They were shot. I saw the bodies. After some time, we were ordered to bury them. Some of the Arab women were forced to help dig.
witnesses.source: Testimony recorded by Teddy Katz, later confirmed in court documents

witnesses.name: Fawziyya Saleh
witnesses.testimony: They made us carry bodies. I saw my teacher, dead. I saw men I knew since childhood, all dead on the beach. The soldiers were laughing and smoking cigarettes.
witnesses.source: Oral history interview, Institute for Palestine Studies

sections.heading: Immediate Impact
items: Coastal Depopulation: Contributed to fear and exodus of Palestinians from coastal villages
Strategic Control: Secured Mediterranean coastline for Israeli state
Suppression: Immediately classified and suppressed from official Israeli history
Precedent: Established pattern of mass execution and concealment used elsewhere during Nakba

sections.heading: The Katz Affair (1998-2000)
items: 1998: MA student Teddy Katz documents massacre through 140+ interviews with veterans and survivors
1999: Alexandroni Brigade veterans sue Katz for libel despite their own testimonies
2000: Under pressure, Katz forced to sign "apology" and retract findings (later withdrew apology)
Result: University of Haifa downgraded his thesis; Katz suffered breakdown from pressure
Impact: Chilling effect on Israeli historical research into 1948 atrocities

sections.heading: Long-term Significance
items: Symbol of historical suppression and denial in Israel
2022 Documentary: 'Tantura' by Alon Schwarz brings renewed attention with soldier testimonies
Ongoing Palestinian demands for excavation of mass graves and proper burial
Part of broader Nakba commemoration and right of return activism
Academic debate about Israeli historical narratives and accountability
Parking lot over mass grave remains as symbol of ongoing erasure

sections.heading: Justice & Accountability

‚ùå Kibbutz Nahsholim built on village ruins - erasure of Palestinian presence

sources.title: Verified Sources
sources.introduction: Documentation based on extensive interviews with Israeli soldiers who participated, Palestinian survivors, academic research, and recent documentary evidence.

list.name: Teddy Katz Research (1998-1999)
list.description: MA thesis based on 140+ interviews with Alexandroni Brigade veterans and Palestinian survivors. Most comprehensive documentation despite forced retraction.

list.name: Tantura Documentary (2022)
list.description: Film by Alon Schwarz featuring recorded testimonies from Alexandroni Brigade veterans confirming the massacre. Released at Sundance 2022.

list.name: Haaretz Investigations
list.description: Extensive reporting on Tantura massacre, Katz affair, and ongoing cover-up. Access to court documents and archived testimonies.

list.name: Institute for Palestine Studies
list.description: Oral history project documenting survivor testimonies, village records, and demographic data. Preservation of Palestinian collective memory.

list.name: Academic Research
list.description: Key works: Ilan Papp√© 'The Ethnic Cleansing of Palestine' (2006), Benny Morris 'The Birth of the Palestinian Refugee Problem Revisited' (2004), Adam Raz archival research.

list.name: Zochrot Organization

list.name: Israeli Military Archives
list.description: Partial documentation of Alexandroni Brigade operations. Many files remain classified or 'disappeared' regarding Tantura.

alert.text: Methodology: Primary evidence comes from testimonies of Israeli soldiers who participated, corroborated by Palestinian survivor accounts and physical evidence (mass graves). Despite legal pressure to retract, research has been repeatedly confirmed by independent sources.

cta.title: Help Preserve Historical Memory
cta.description: Support ongoing documentation efforts to preserve historical truth and honor victims. Demand excavation and proper burial of Tantura victims.
